title-group.article-title: MCB: Implementation of the Symbols Project

contrib-group.aff: This case was written by Dr Khawaja Asjad Saeed (khawaja.Saeed@wichita.edu) at Wichita State University, USA and Dr Shazib E. Shaikh (shazib@lums.edu.pk) at the Lahore University of Management Sciences, to serve as basis for class discussion rather than to illustrate either effective or ineffective handling of an administrative situation. Special thanks to Faisal Ejaz Khan, Rashid Jahangir, Faraz Ahmed, Qasim Naseer and Ayesha for their time and assistance. This case study was originally funded by the visiting scholar program (at Hailey College of Banking and Finance) sponsored by the Higher Education Commission of Pakistan. This material may not be quoted, photocopied or reproduced in any form without the prior written consent of the Lahore University of Management Sciences.

abstract.p: This is a case that facilitates learning about IT-enabled change management. It tracks both the decision to convert to a $1.7 million banking enterprise system and its roll-out between 2002 and 2008. The project was met with resistance by the branches of this major nationwide bank to the point that in 2005 the project team was completely reorganized and a new Senior Vice President (SVP) position was created specifically for the project. The new system would lead to more centralization and integration with faster inter-branch processing as compared to the previous system which granted branches more autonomy in inter-bank transfers and employees only interacted with the system through data operators. Recognizing customers at the bank level and not just at branch level was an important objective. The complete project reorganization allows readers to understand the need to appreciate certain factors that may be deemed as trivial, especially where top-down IT enabled change is being implemented. At the end of the case, the project is still in progress with 818 branches (76 per cent) converted to the new system.
